perturbation.original_text: 5.7 Payment for Products. Todos shall invoice the Reseller for all sums due for Products ordered upon shipment of the ordered Products to the Reseller, and the Reseller shall pay such sums by no later than thirty (30) days from the date of shipment. All payments made to Todos shall be in New Israeli Shekels.
perturbation.changed_text: 5.7 Payment for Products. Todos shall invoice the Reseller for all sums due for Products ordered upon shipment of the ordered Products to the Reseller, and the Reseller shall pay such sums by no later than ninety (90) days from the date of shipment. All payments made to Todos shall be in New Israeli Shekels.
perturbation.explanation: In Israel, the 'Payment Clearing Law' mandates that payment terms exceeding 60 days require explicit justification and agreement. Extending the payment deadline to 90 days without such justification creates a contradiction with Israeli payment laws, potentially rendering the clause unenforceable without proper documentation.

perturbation.original_text: 6.2 Quarterly Reports. Within fifteen (15) days of the end of each quarter, the Reseller shall provide Todos with a written report of (a) the quantities of Products distributed, sold, or otherwise transferred; the prices at which the Products were sold; and payments received therefore; and (b) the identity and location of all Customers to whom Products were sold, during the preceding quarter (each a "Quarterly Report").
perturbation.changed_text: 6.2 Quarterly Reports. Within forty-five (45) days of the end of each quarter, the Reseller shall provide Todos with a written report of (a) the quantities of Products distributed, sold, or otherwise transferred; the prices at which the Products were sold; and payments received therefore; and (b) the identity and location of all Customers to whom Products were sold, during the preceding quarter (each a "Quarterly Report").
perturbation.explanation: The Israeli Companies Law mandates timely and accurate financial reporting. Unduly delaying the submission of quarterly reports to 45 days, without a reasonable basis can conflict with legal obligations for prompt financial disclosure and transparency.

perturbation.original_text: 11.2 Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, a party may terminate this Agreement upon the occurrence of any of the following events, and such party shall not be liable to the other party for the proper exercise of such right: (a) The other party materially breaches this Agreement and continues in such breach for thirty (30) days after the non-breaching party has given written notice thereof to the other party; or (b) For a period of ninety (90) consecutive days, the other party is declared to be insolvent or is the subject of bankruptcy or liquidation proceedings, whether compulsory or voluntary, or has a receiver, judicial administrator or similar officer appointed over all or any material part of its assets, or any security holder or encumbrance lawfully takes possession of any property of or in possession of the other party, or if the other party ceases to carry on its business.
perturbation.changed_text: 11.2 Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, a party may terminate this Agreement upon the occurrence of any of the following events, and such party shall not be liable to the other party for the proper exercise of such right: (a) The other party materially breaches this Agreement and continues in such breach for ten (10) days after the non-breaching party has given written notice thereof to the other party; or (b) For a period of thirty (30) consecutive days, the other party is declared to be insolvent or is the subject of bankruptcy or liquidation proceedings, whether compulsory or voluntary, or has a receiver, judicial administrator or similar officer appointed over all or any material part of its assets, or any security holder or encumbrance lawfully takes possession of any property of or in possession of the other party, or if the other party ceases to carry on its business.
perturbation.explanation: Under Israeli contract law, particularly concerning commercial agreements, providing an unreasonably short cure period (10 days) for a material breach may be deemed insufficient and conflict with the principle of good faith and fair dealing. Similarly, requiring termination for insolvency after only 30 days could violate bankruptcy laws protecting businesses attempting to reorganize. A reasonable timeframe must be allowed for remediation of the breach and the insolvency.
